bibl.title: Letter from R. C. Derivaux to Henry Rose Carter, July 16, 1922

div1.p: Derivaux reports on work done in the field of acidosis and diabetes. He has done no more work on malaria since going into private practice.

div1.head: Letter from R. C. Derivaux to Henry Rose Carter, July 16, 1922
div1.opener:
Miss
Derivaux
DR. R.C. DERIVAUX
DOCTORS' BUILDING
NASHVILLE, TENNESSEE
July 16, 1922.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter, -the one you said was not a
letter but merely an inquiry as to whether you had
sent me a copy of your report “Yellow Fever in Peru”,
has been on my desk for reply since its receipt about
ten days ago.

In answer to the question, No! And I might add
that I would like much to have a copy if you can still
spare one. As you have often told me it is very doubtful
-now particularly, that I shall ever have any opportunity
to put what information I may have gathered as to Y.F. to
any practical use. But I should like to have the report
for my files and because it is field work of yours. If you
can spare two copies, I shall be glad to put the other one
in the library of the Vanderbilt Medical School here.

I have continued busy since I wrote you last. While
work is in a measure slack at this season, I have been doing
quite a lot of reading and laboratory work in the field of
acidosis and diabetes, which latter subject is absorbing much
of my time and displacing some of the malaria knowledge for
which I have found but little use since going into
private work.

Remember me cordially to everyone. With all good
regards and wishes,
